text.p: China's parliament, the National People's Congress, approved on Friday the budget for 1997.
However, some 10 percent of the 2,720 deputies did not vote for the budget, with 126 voting no and 122 abstaining while 30 did not vote.
The budget revealed a record debt issue and higher defence spending for 1997.
China aims to cut its budget deficit by 7.2 percent to 57.0 billion yuan ($6.87 billion) in 1997 from 61.442 billion last year, Finance Minister Liu Zhongli said last week.

Total revenues were expected to be 839.794 billion yuan ($101.18 billion) this year, an increase of 14 percent, while expenditures were set at 896.794 billion yuan ($108.047 billion), up by 13.3 percent.
However, Liu said China would miss its target to balance its books by the end of the century.
Western diplomats say the deficit is manageable, equal to about 0.77 percent of estimated total GDP this year and down from 0.99 percent last year.
